__data__.text: Nightlife in Belgrade has a rich history, with the first kafana, an Ottoman-style bistro, opening in 1522. Belgrade had a significant number of kafanas and meyhanas during the Austrian rule in the 18th century, with the Duke of Württemberg encouraging their growth by abolishing tax on drink serving. These venues were important social institutions, serving as gathering spots for various classes and political parties. The kafanas evolved over time, with westernized venues emerging in the 19th century. Despite laws against staying up late, kafanas became centers of city social life, with some historians describing them as the "most important institutions" from the 19th century to World War II. The diversification of kafanas led to the emergence of various types, including mehana, bistro, gostionica, han, saraj, lokal, krčma, bircuz, birtija, and later restoran and hotel. The kafanas were not only places to drink, but also to eat, rest, and sleepover, with many offering music. The first hotel, "Kod jelena," was built in 1843 and introduced European entertainment traditions. The first ball in Belgrade was held in 1838, and they became more frequent after 1860, with a strict timetable and etiquette. In contrast, "potato balls" were popular among the lower classes, especially in suburban kafanas.

In Belgrade, kafanas evolved from Ottoman-style bistros to diverse social institutions, including "Esnafska kafana," "Makedonija," and "Kod Albanije," which catered to different groups and political parties. The first hotel, "Kod jelena," introduced European entertainment traditions and hosted the first ball in Belgrade. Kafanas offered various experiences, from formal balls to "potato balls" for the lower classes. The first all-night kafana opened in the mid-19th century, and by 1893, electrified streetlamps extended nightlife. Kafanas had unique and creative names, often in contrast to nearby venues. The "Srpska kruna" and "Dardaneli" kafanas were particularly famous for their social significance and clientele. Skadarlija became the central nightlife point in Belgrade as older kafanas were demolished. As of 2023, "Tri šešira" is the oldest operational kafana in Skadarlija and the second oldest in Belgrade.

In the late 19th and early 20th century, kafanas in Belgrade evolved and grew in popularity, with unique and creative names, and some becoming social institutions. Skadarlija became the central nightlife point as older kafanas were demolished, including "Velika Srbija" and "Bajlonijeva kafana." The Bibija stream, flowing through Skadarlija, marked the administrative border between Palilula and Dorćol quarters, with different regulations on music and nightlife. Prostitution was prevalent in some kafanas, like "Despotov Han," but largely suppressed by the Circle of Serbian Sisters. By the Interbellum, there was one hospitality venue per 50 inhabitants, with luxurious hotels and nightlife locales, like "Srpski Kralj," contrasting with small cookshops and soup kitchens for the lower classes. The first official ban on nightlife, known as the "tax for nighttime sitting," was implemented in 1927. Important kafanas from this period include "Babuna," "Bajlonijeva kafana," "Boem," "Bulevar," "Bums Keler," "Cvetkova mehana," "Čukareva kafana," "Dva bela goluba," "Era Gurman," "Građanska kasina," "Kazbek," and "London."

In the early 20th century, Belgrade's kafanas and restaurants flourished, with new venues opening and some becoming social institutions. Skadarlija emerged as the central nightlife hub, with kafanas like "Dva duda" and "Kazbek" becoming popular. "Građanska kasina" was known for its well-regarded grilled and roasted meat and was a gathering place for respected merchants and high-ranking officers. "London" was a prominent kafana and korzo (promenade) located near the National Assembly. "Manakova kuća" in Savamala, originally a Turkish agha's house, became a meyhane and bakery, while "Zeleni Venac" started as a kafana with a green wreath on its façade and gave its name to the surrounding neighborhood. "Zlatni krst" was known for hosting the first cinema show in Belgrade in 1896.

In the early 20th century, Belgrade's kafanas (traditional taverns) flourished and became social institutions, with new ones opening and some becoming popular hubs for nightlife. Skadarlija emerged as the central nightlife area, with venues like "Dva duda" and "Kazbek" gaining popularity. Other notable kafanas included "Građanska kasina," known for its grilled and roasted meat and a gathering place for respected merchants and high-ranking officers, and "Zeleni Venac," which started as a kafana with a green wreath on its façade and gave its name to the surrounding neighborhood. "Zlatni krst" was known for hosting the first cinema show in Belgrade in 1896. After the World War I, many kafanas became centers of nightlife, including those adjoined to sports clubs and stadiums. In the mid-1950s, renovated "Lotos Bar" was opened and became an instant sensation with its artistic program, which included magicians, jugglers, and barely dressed female dancers. This led to the opening of similar venues and the development of street prostitution in the late 1960s. In the 2010s, some elite prostitutes became reality TV stars, known as "starlets." New Belgrade, built from 1948, had no nightlife for a long time, but traditional kafanas survived and remained part of Belgrade's tourist offer. Skadarlija, known as the main bohemian quarter of Belgrade, remains the second most visited attraction in Belgrade after the Belgrade Fortress, contributing to one third of the city's foreign currency income.

The text discusses the historical and cultural significance of kafanas in Belgrade, with a focus on Skadarlija and Čubura, two neighborhoods known for their bohemian character. Skadarlija, also known as the "soul of Belgrade," emerged in the 19th century and became a hub for artists and bohemians. It is now the second most visited attraction in Belgrade, contributing to one third of the city's foreign currency income. Čubura, once a gathering place for common people, had a more laid-back atmosphere compared to the fashionable Skadarlija. However, by the 2020s, Čubura's bohemianism had been extinguished, with kafanas closing one by one and the "spirit of Čubura" disappearing. The text also mentions some famous kafanas outside of Skadarlija, such as "?" and "Bled," which have been in operation for over a century. In recent years, traditional kafanas have survived and remained part of Belgrade's tourist offer, despite the development of westernized restaurants and modern nightlife venues.

The text highlights several well-known kafanas and restaurants in Belgrade, both historic and contemporary, which have played a significant role in the city's social and cultural life. These establishments include "?", the oldest operating kafana, and "Bled," a famous fish restaurant. The "Golf" kafana, built in the 1930s, was a gathering place for important figures and later became a training facility for a hospitality school. "Hotel Moskva" is mentioned for its historical significance as a social hub where governments were formed or toppled. Other notable kafanas include "Kalenić," "Klub Književnika," "Kolarac," "Lipov lad," "Madera," "Mornar," "Orašac," "Polet," "Poslednja Šansa," "Proleće," "Ruski car," "Srpska kafana," "Stara Hercegovina," and "Sunce," each with its unique history and significance. Some of these establishments have been renovated or reopened in recent years, while others have faced threats of demolition or closure.

Several well-known kafanas and restaurants in Belgrade, with historical and cultural significance, are highlighted in the text. These establishments include "Srpska kafana," opened in 1923, which became a special place for the actors and staff of Atelje 212 after it moved nearby. "Stara Hercegovina," previously named "Skoplje," is known as a gastronomical hub in Stari Grad. "Sunce," opened in 1966, was an exclusive restaurant and gathering place for Belgrade's elite. "Šaran," established in 1896, was initially a gathering place for local fishermen and ferry passengers. "Ušće," built in 1960, was a well-known restaurant until its closure in the 1990s and was later refurbished and reopened as "Nacionalna klasa" in 2017. "Venecija," opened in 1913, was a famous fish restaurant and a popular gathering place for Belgrade's elite. "Zlatno burence," opened in 1866, was a gathering point for members of the Serbian Chetnik Organization and volunteers in the Serbian-Turkish and Balkan Wars. The "Bermuda Triangle," a colloquial name for three rival kafanas in Makedonska Street, was known for its bohemian clientele, including famous artists, writers, and journalists.

Additionally, the text mentions several well-known venues that have closed, including "Atina," which was popular in the 1970s and 1980s and was the first pizzeria in Belgrade. "Buffet of Hotel Bristol," known for its mix of cultural and non-cultural clientele, had its interior unchanged from the 1960s until the hotel's closure in 2018. "Grgeč," a favorite spot for journalists and reporters, was closed in 2007 and replaced by a McDonald's restaurant. "Kasina," established in 1858, was named after the Italian word "casino" due to some gambling organized in it.

The text highlights several historical and culturally significant kafanas and restaurants in Belgrade, such as "Srpska kafana," "Stara Hercegovina," "Sunce," "Šaran," "Ušće," "Venecija," and "Zlatno burence." These establishments have played various roles in the city's history, serving as gathering places for locals, cultural figures, and even soldiers during wars. Some, like "Atina," "Buffet of Hotel Bristol," and "Grgeč," have closed and been replaced by modern businesses. The text also notes the historical significance of kafanas in Belgrade, serving as the first democratic spaces and playing a crucial role in the city's economy and social life. Numerous historical events have taken place in these kafanas, such as the first game of billiard in Belgrade and the official celebration of the city's handover from the Ottomans to the Serbs.

Kafanas in Belgrade have played a significant historical and cultural role as the first democratic spaces, serving as venues for various significant events and the initiation of important institutions. They were central to the city's economy and social life, allowing for the participation of lower classes in economic activities. Numerous firsts in Belgrade's history occurred in kafanas, including the establishment of the first bank, exchange office, labor market, stock exchange, insurance office, private medical office, photographic studio, and more. Important kafanas included "Zisina kafana," "Kod Paje kantardžije," and "Tri lista duvana." Numerous historical events took place in kafanas, such as the first game of billiard, the first assembly of the parliament, official celebrations, and the founding of important institutions like the Red Cross of Serbia and the Serbian Journalists Association. Kafanas also played a role in the development of Belgrade's nightlife, with the first public clock, book fair, and dance nights taking place in or near them. The first night clubs, referred to as "disko[teka]" in Serbian, were opened in the late 1960s as a result of the popularity of rock and roll. The first clubs were small and located in private houses and apartments, with the authorities trying to close them down. The Euridika club, opened in 1961, was one of the most important cultural hotspots in the late 1960s, hosting performances by various popular bands and launching the careers of some performers. The club was an offshoot of the Youth Theater DADOV and was closed in the late 1970s.

The first disco clubs in Belgrade emerged in the 1960s, with "Euridika" opening in 1961 as an offshoot of the Youth Theater DADOV, and "Kod Laze Šećera" opening in 1967, becoming a popular cultural hotspot for the international jet-set. The Belgrade Youth Center, opened in 1964, introduced the discothèque "202" in 1969, which was noted for its lack of incidents and as a meeting place for the wealthy. KST, unofficially established in 1952, became a popular venue for students and musicians, promoting young musicians and hosting important Yugoslav rock-groups. The "Studentski Kulturni Centar" (SKC) opened in 1968 and became a hub for the punk subculture after punk music arrived in Belgrade. These clubs played a significant role in Belgrade's cultural and nightlife scene, facing various challenges from authorities and neighbors.

In the 1960s and 70s, Belgrade's nightlife scene evolved with the emergence of disco clubs, such as "Euridika," "Kod Laze Šećera," and "KST," which promoted young musicians and hosted important Yugoslav rock-groups. "KST" gained cult status among city youth and was known for its relaxed dress code and diverse events. Meanwhile, "Studentski Kulturni Centar" (SKC) became a hub for the punk subculture and alternative rock music. During the 1970s, Belgrade saw an increase in international events and Western European influence, with rock and roll gaining popularity. Disco clubs turned into exclusive venues with high entry fees, leading to visitors smuggling alcohol. Clubs like "Cepelin" and "Akvarijus" gained popularity, with the latter attracting the city's elite. "Cepelin," once the most famous disco in Yugoslavia, was closed in 1980, while "Akvarijus" remained open all night for its exclusive members.

In the 1960s and 70s, Belgrade's nightlife scene evolved with the emergence of disco clubs, such as "Euridika," "Kod Laze Šećera," and "KST," which promoted young musicians and hosted important Yugoslav rock-groups. During the 1970s, Belgrade saw an increase in international events and Western European influence, with rock and roll gaining popularity. Disco clubs turned into exclusive venues with high entry fees, leading to visitors smuggling alcohol.

Two notable clubs that emerged during this time were "Cepelin" and "Akvarijus." "Cepelin," once the most famous disco in Yugoslavia, was closed in 1980 and replaced with a different venue called "Taš." "Akvarijus," located at 7 Deligradska Street near the Slavija Square, was known for its fancy clientele, consisting of rich lawyers, politicians, and athletes. It was open all night and played music by international artists such as the Bee Gees, Boney M, Éric Charden, and Amanda Lear.

Other clubs included "Crveni Pevac," a rock place in Topličin Venac visited by bikers, "F(ilozof)," a venue founded by the youth organization of the University of Belgrade Faculty of Philosophy, "Mažestik," an exclusive disco club, "Monokl," a club opened in bohemian Skadarlija, "Resnik," a club located in the suburb of Resnik, and "Duga," a club patterned after the wishes of the rich and opened to gather the rich and famous.

In the 1980s, DJs became stars in their own right, with Zoran Modli being the most popular. "Akademija," one of the most famous and influential clubs in Belgrade, was opened at 53 Knez Mihailova Street in 1981. It was a rock and roll venue and a meeting place for rockers, artists, politicians' children, and young and avant-garde rebels. The original line-up of Ekaterina Velika gathered here, and other musicians who performed included Električni Orgazam, Partibrejkers, Psi

In the 1980s, Belgrade saw an expansion of new disco clubs, including "Bezistan," "Bona Fides," "Crveni podijum," "Cvetni Breg," "London," "Panorama," and "Šestica." These clubs were popular and had unique features, such as being the only "dancing club" in the city or offering a panoramic view of the city. However, they were often located in basements or adapted utility rooms and could be stuffy. In the late 1970s, the first barge-clubs, known as splavovi, began to appear, with "Argument" being the first restaurant on a splav, opened in 1983. The 1990s were marked by calamities, including the break-up of Yugoslavia and wars, which led to the rise of criminal activity and the popularity of turbo-folk music in disco clubs. By the 2010s, there were over 200 cafes, restaurants, kafanas, and discos on the barges. The splavovi have remained publicly connected with criminals and numerous incidents. In the late 2010s, all barges were moved out of Staro Sajmište due to public conflict. Despite international sanctions, electronic music venues and a techno and rave scene developed in the second half of the 1990s. The "Lukas" splav gained notoriety in the 1990s for its association with criminal clans and shootings.

The "Lukas" club, open in the 1980s and famous in the 1990s, was located on the left bank of the Sava River and became a gathering place for criminal clans. It was the site of a major shootout in 1994 and was associated with numerous crimes and gangsters. The club was closed and reopened, but it gained a reputation as a place to avoid. In 2017, a member of a soccer supporter group was killed outside the club. The "Industrija" club, opened in 1994, was a popular techno rave venue that played only electronic music and hosted foreign DJs. It is described as writing the history of the Serbian electronic scene. Other notable clubs in Belgrade during this time included "Apartman," "Batler," "Francuska Sobarica," "Bordel," "Buha," "Bus," "Dolar," "Energija," "Inkognito," "Gajba," "Kuća," "Lale Happy People," "Luv," "Magna House," "Omen," "Pećina," "Sara," "Soul Food," "Triton," "Trozubac," and "Tube." Many of these clubs were associated with criminal activity and were the site of shootings and other crimes. The clubbing scene in Belgrade during the 1990s was marked by the rise of turbo-folk music, the development of electronic music venues despite international sanctions, and the association of clubs with criminal activity.
